characters: A MODEL OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM
S E C O N D GUARD

dialogues.speaker: HIBERNATING GROUNDHOGS
dialogues.text: A family of groundhogs is nestled together in their burro sleeping off the end of a long winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crust of an old snowfall still covers the frozen grou and the bare, icy branches of the trees glisten dully in early morning light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHIL CONNORS is standing in front of a blank green wall gesticulating animatedly at some invisible images on the talking a mile a minute (MOS) . He looks completely crazy points at nothing and winks to an unseen audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CREDITS CONTINUE as we streak across the winter landscape flying over fields and farms, small towns and hamlets, ra lines and interstates, coalyards and factories, until we the Allegheny River and follow it to the southwest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil continues pointing out features on the blank wall , from a new angle we can see that he ' s looking at a moni of the corner of his eye which shows the chromakey insert pointing to -- a national weather map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The country towns turn to suburbs, traffic on the roads g heavier and finally we see the skyline of Pittsburgh and confluence of the Allegheny with the Monongahela and the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We zoom into a tall building in the downtown area and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't see anyone at first but the office itself speaks volumes about it's inhabitant-- team pictures of the Stee from the Franco Harris-Terry Bradshaw glory years, a fram memorial portrait of Roberto Clemente, a local Emmy award statue, an erasable weather map and mountains of personal on the desk, ^windowsill, and every other available surfa As the CREDITS END, we notice a sleeping figure on the sm sofa, buried deep under a pile of coats and a stolen airl blanket. GIL HAWLEY, Executive Producer of the Action News, sticks head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: HAWLEY
dialogues.text: Christ, what a pit. Phil" The sleeping figure rouses himself and looks out at Hawle It's Phil, the .Channel 9 Action News weatherman.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (SLEEPY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HAWLEY
dialogues.text: It's February first, Phil. You know what tomorrow is? Phil sits up and.thinks hard. He's in his mid-thirties, s rugged-looking, perhaps a little too full of himself, but clearly a guy with a lot of personality.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (catching on) Oh, no! Not again. He jumps up and exits the office with Hawley right behind

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Forget it! I'm not going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawley pursues Phil through the office suite of the Chann Action News, from the look of it a typical, big city, loc news operation. A logo on the wall identifies the station WPGH - Pittsburgh. Phil ducks into the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawley follows him in and catches up with him at the weat corner of the Action News set. Phil starts putting weathe stats up on a chart.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Get away from me. I'm working.

dialogues.speaker: HAWLEY
dialogues.text: So what's the outlook? We gonna get that blizzard? Phil shakes his head and points to the chart which is hea "Phil's Phorecast" with a cute caricature of himself draw to the title.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No way. All that moisture coming up from the Gulf is going to miss us completely and take a dump on Harrisburg.

dialogues.speaker: HAWLEY
dialogues.text: (with authority) Good, 'cause you're going up to Punxsutawney to cover the groundhog story tomorrow morning and I want you back here in time to do the five.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Jesus, Gil, give me a break, will you! I covered the goddamn groundhog last year and the year before that.

dialogues.speaker: HAWLEY
dialogues.text: And you'll do it :next year and the year after, too. When I worked in San Diego, I covered the swallows coming back to Capistrano for ten years in a row.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You should've killed the guy who made you do that.

dialogues.speaker: HAWLEY
dialogues.text: I wanted to do it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Then you should've killed yourself. I don't want to get stuck with the groundhog for the rest of my life.

dialogues.speaker: HAWLEY
dialogues.text: It's a cute story. He comes out, he looks around, he wrinkles up his little nose, he sniffs around a little, he sees his shadow, he d oesn't see his shadow-- it's nice. People like it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Many people are morons.

dialogues.speaker: HAWLEY
dialogues.text: Just do it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What'11 you give me? Hawley looks across the studio and sees RITA HANSON enter very attractive segment producer in her late twenties.

dialogues.speaker: HAWLEY
dialogues.text: (to Phil) I'll give you Rita. (calls her over) Rita, could you come here for a second? I got a little job for you. Rita is relatively new to the station, but very competent personable, humorous, self-assured and very pretty-- in s a genuine princess, though Phil is too self-absorbed at t point to realize it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (TEASING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't send Rita out on a story like this. She's just a cub, a pup, still wet behind the ears. Look at her. Her ears are sopping wet. This needs a Woodward or a Bernstein. It's a big story. People need to know.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (INTRIGUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the story?

dialogues.speaker: HAWLEY
dialogues.text: The Punxsutawney Groundhog Festival.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Gil, if it's all right with you I ' d rather follow-up on the nurses' strike.

dialogues.speaker: HAWLEY
dialogues.text: You can do the nurses when you get back. Just take the squeaky wheel here up to Punxsutawney and get him back in one piece. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. Hawley exits leaving Phil and Rita alone in the studio. S knows Phil mainly by his reputation and it isn't good. St she finds him appealing in an odd way.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (PLEASANTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, this could be extremely interesting.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I've never done a weather story before. What's Punxsutawney like?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh, it's an enchanted place. A magical world. It's the Constantinople of the whole Western Appalachian-Susquehanna Drainage system.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Do you always joke?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: About 70 to 80% of the time. Inside I'm actually a very shy and sensitive person.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: A lot of people around here think you're not very sincere.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Tell me the names of these people.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I'll line up a crew and transportation. If you don't feel like driving, we can all go up in the van together.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I think I'll take my own car. I ' m not that fond of my fellow man.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (EXITING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice attitude.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Nice face. (calls after her) Why don't you ride up with me?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No, thanks. STEPHANIE DECASTRO , an attractive, dark-eyed, dark-haire correspondent, glares at Phil from across the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is in his cluttered cubicle talking on a headset pho while he reviews cassettes of his groundhog spots from th two years on a small monitor. As he talks, he stuffs a nu of personal items in an overnight bag, all the time watch himself on the TV monitor.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (on the phone) They don't really think of me as a weatherman around here. More of a "personality," but with the credibility of a first-class broadcast journalist. Once you look at my tape I think you'll see what they mean. Stephanie enters and stands in the doorway looking at Phi a long moment. There is something vaguely off-center abou this woman, not quite FATAL ATTRACTION but still a little scary.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: (BITTERLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to know one thing: did I do something wrong or are you just tired of me or what? I have to know. Phil sighs.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Dan, can I call you back? I've just been handed something and I better get on it... (he picks up some papers and rustles them for effect) ...Okay, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off the headset, gets up and closes the door for privacy.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (KINDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't do anything wrong, Stephanie, and I ' m not tired of you. It's just that I don't have time for a real relationship right now. I told you that the first time we went out.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: (getting close) Everybody says that at the beginning of a relationship.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (gently pushing her

dialogues.speaker: AWAY
dialogues.text: I'm different. I really meant it! Things are really starting to move for me now. I ' m not going to be doing the weather for the rest of my life. I was just talking to the CBS guy about a network job. I want that. This is just the beginning for me. I can't waste any more time.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Are you saying our relationship was a waste of time?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Our relationship? We went out a total of four times! And only twice did anything happen. It was fun but I don't see that as a big commitment.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: (closing in again) I had our charts done. My astrologer says we're extremely compatible. There may even be some past lives involvement here.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: See? So we've already done this. Let's move on. Next case.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: You know what's wrong with you, Phil? You're selfish. You don't have time for anyone but yourself.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: That's what I ' m trying to tell you. You don't want to be with me. You can do better. Look, Stephanie, if I ever said or did anything to mislead you I'm sorry for that, but right now I have to do this groundhog thing and I don't have a handle on it yet. He throws some papers and his datebook into a briefcase a puts on his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what. I ' m going to do some serious thinking while I ' m in Punxsutawney, okay? He pats her on the shoulder and brushes past her, leaving standing there with a malevolent look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VAN marked ".Channel 9 Action News" speeds along a two- highway through the winter landscape of West Central Pennsylvania. Mounted atop the van is a microwave transmi Rita is riding up front with LARRY, the union cameraman a techie. Phil is following close behind the van in a new L coupe. His car has a bumper-sticker that reads "Weatherme Like it Wet."

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on his earphone) I'm on my way to Punxsutawney... (forced to repeat it, a little embarrassed) Punx^su-taw-ney....Work or fun? I think that all depends on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is talking to one of his girlfriends, sorting throug stack of CD's, as usual, grabbing at the good life with b hands.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: . . . . I thought maybe you could meet me up there tonight and let me vulgarize you for about seven hours....So I ' m supposed to spend the night in Punxsutawney all alo ne? Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil loads a CD and a great, driving song kicks in.

dialogues.speaker: A SIGN
dialogues.text: "Welcome to Punxsutawney - The Original Weather Capitol o World Since 1887." Depicted on the sign is a large cartoo GROUNDHOG wearing a top hat and clutching an umbrella und arm. The mini-convoy passes some fast food places on the outsk of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van drives along , the small-town main drag. There ar cartoon groundhogs everywhere you look and the whole town been gaily festooned with banners and bunting.

dialogues.speaker: EXT . MOTEL
dialogues.text: The van pulls into the parking lot at a Quality Inn. The announcement billboard in ;front of the motel reads: "Gro Day Breakfast Special - Feb.2 - All You Can Eat - $5.99." parking area is already crowded with cars including a num other news vans. The Lexus pulls in behind the van and everybody gets out. Phil takes one look at the motel and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (calls out) Rita! I can't stay here. Rita is already helping Larry unload equipment from the v

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (MUTTERING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prima donnas.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It's okay. I'll handle it. She crosses to the Lexus where Phil is trying to make ano call on his earphone.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What's the problem, Phil?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I hate this place. I stayed here two years ago and I was miserable. It's like a minimum security prison. I'm not staying here.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You're not staying here.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (BRIGHTENING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ' m not?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No, Larry and I don't care but I thought you might, so I booked you at a very nice bed and breakfast on Cherry Street. Here's the address. She hands him a card.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (PLEASED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. That's great. That's the mark of a really good producer. Making the talent happy.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Whatever I can do.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Really? Will you be my love slave?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Whatever I can do within reason. Would you like to have dinner with Larry and me?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No thanks, I've seen Larry eat. Why don't you ditch Larry and let me take you someplace nice?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You mean like a date?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Okay. I get it. You're a little intimidated by me, you're all excited about the shoot tomorrow, you want everything to go just perfect. I understand. You just get some sleep. Tomorrow will be great.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well, that's something to look forward to. I'll see you in the morning. He drives off, leaving her standing there shaking her hea

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Did he actually call himself "the talent?" Larry snorts and continues unloading their gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first light of morning colors the sky behind the Cher Street Inn, a rambling, white Victorian bed and breakfast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A digital clock-radio changes from 5:59 to 6:00 AM. The r comes on, playing the end of the Sonny and Cher hit, "I G You, Babe."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil sits up in bed and looks around the room. The decor typical bed and breakfast, flocked wallpaper, framed prin and an odd assortment of mismatched furniture. His suit i hanging neatly on the back of the closet door and his sui is open on a stand at the foot of the bed, still neatly p A iradio, DEEJAY and his SIDEKICK come on with hyped-up, drivetime Chappy talk." Phil stares at the radio and list to them.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: Okay, campers, rise and shine, and don't forget your booties because it's COOOLD out there

dialogues.speaker: TODAY1
dialogues.text: Phil grimaces and swings out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: SIDEK ICK
dialogues.text: It's cold out there everyday. W hat is this-- Miami Beach? The deejay laughs. Phil shakes his head at the cheesy rep as he crosses to the sink and starts brushing his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: Not hardly. And you can expect hazardous travel later today with that, you know, blizzard thing--

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: That "blizzard thing?" Phil splashes some water on his face and prepares to shav

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Oh, here's the report: the National Weather Service is calling for a big blizzard thing.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: Yes they are, but there's another reason today is very special--

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: Es pec ia lly cold--

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: Especially cold, okay, but the big question on everybody's lips--

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: Ch ap pe d lips--

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: :--on their chapped lips, right-- Do you think Phil's going to come out and see his shadow?

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: Punxsutawney Phil. Phil looks up at himself in the mirror, admiring his own

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: That's right, rodent lovers!

dialogues.speaker: BOTH DEEJAYS
dialogues.text: Groundhog Day1 SOUND EFFECT of GRUNTING GROUNDHOGS. Phil grunts at his reflection in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to himself) Never again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil heads for the breakfast room of the inn, now well-dr in a suit and tie, a nice overcoat slung over his arm. A CHUBBY MAN passes.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY MAN
dialogues.text: Morning .

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Morning .

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY MAN
dialogues.text: Think it'll be an early Spring?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I ' m predicting March 21st.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil enters the old library of the house now set up with breakfast buffet. An old spinet piano stands in the corne One wall is lined with .bookcases filled with books. A ha of guests are seated around the room, eating. The matron of the house, MRS. LANCASTER, spots Phil as sh comes out of the kitchen with a fresh pot of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: Did you sleep well, Mr. Connors?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (with mock civility) Like a Roumanian orphan, Mrs. Lancaster.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: Would you like some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I don't suppose it1 d be possible to get an espresso or a capuccino around here.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: (BLANKLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really know --

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Forget it. This '11 be fine.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: ( as she pours) I wonder what the weather's going to be like for all the festivities.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: My guess is it'11 be cold and overcast, high today in the low 30's, dropping to the low 20's tonight, but I'm predicting that all that moisture coming up from the Gulf is going to miss us and dump some locally heavy snow, possibly blizzard conditions with travel advisories in the Harrisburg area and maybe as far east as .Philadelphia. (off her surprised

dialogues.speaker: LOOK
dialogues.text: You want to talk weather, you asked the right guy. He heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, will you be checking out today, Mr. Connors?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Unfortunately yes. Phil exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sipping at the steaming coffee, Phil manages to put on hi and gloves as he descends the front steps of the house an joins the flow of pedestrian traffic on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a lot of people on the street for this hour. Tr is so heavy in fact, the pedestrians are moving faster th cars. Everyone seems to be going in the same direction, m the annual trek to see the groundhog. An OLD BUM is sitting on the sidewalk leaning against a storefront. Someone throws him a coin. Phil walks by with taking any notice.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Phil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big pie-faced man, NED RYERSON, comes huffing and puffi right up to him. There is something about this guy that m us dislike him on sight.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Phil! Phil Connors! I thought that was you! Phil looks at him vaguely.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (at a loss) I 'm sorry. Have we-- uh--

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: My oh my! Phil Connors. Don't say you don't remember me, 'cause I sure as heckrfire remember you. Well? Phil stares, trying to remember.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Ned Ryerson? Needlenose Ned? Ned the Head. Come on, buddy. Case Western High?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Ned?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I see you clicking through that brain of yours. Click-click, c li ck- cli ck, click-click--Bing! Ned Ryerson, did the whistling trick with my belly button in the talent show. Bing! Ned Ryerson, got the shingles real bad senior ^year^ almost didn't graduate. Bing again! Ned Ryerson, went out with your sister Mary Pat a couple of times-- 'til you told me not to anymore. Well?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (RESIGNED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned Ryerson.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Bing!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So what're you doing with yourself, Ned?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Phil, I sell insurance.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (sorry he asked) No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Do you have life insurance, Phil? 'Cause if you do, I bet you could u s e more-- who couldn't?--but I got a feeling you don't have any. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You know, Ned, I ' d love to talk to you but I really have to-- Phil starts to walk away,,but Ned won't take the hint.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: That's okay. I'll walk with you. When I see an opportunity, I charge it, like a bull. Ned the Bull, that's me now. Some of my friends live and die by actuarial tables, but I think it's all just a crap shoot anyhoo. Ever heard of single .premium life? That could be the ticket for you, buddy. God, it's good to see you! Hey, what're you doing for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Dinner? Umm, I don't think that's going to work for me. As they continue walking, Phil steps into what looks like shallow puddle and ends up ankle deep in wet slush. Ned l like a donkey.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Hey, look out for that first step! It's a doozy! Phil looks at him with murderous contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big crowd is standing in a park-like clearing off a residential street. They are gathered around a large moun dirt enclosed by a rail fence, waiting for the big moment a cold gray dawn, there is the atmosphere of a festival h An area close to the mound is roped off for news reporter cameras. Rita stands there, a pocket of genuine beauty in sea of potbellied old union guys and blow-dried reporters

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stomping her feet against the cold, Rita looks at her wat glances around. Larry, the cameraman, just looks bored.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: How could he be late?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Prima donnas.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It's just so-- inconsiderate.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What happens to some people? They're born nice. They grow up nice. You put 'em on TV and - bam! Prima donnas. Rita spots Phil heading into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Here he comes. Phil! Hey, Phil. Over here! Phil joins them in the press area. Rita pulls him to his near the rail fence.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Where've you been?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I got hung up with some jerk I went to high school with. So, did you sleep okay without me? You tossed and turned, didn't you? Rita holds up a slate for Larry to ID the tape.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You're incredible.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Who told you?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Ready when you are. Phil takes the microphone from Rita and positions himself against the fence. The Groundhog Club Officials in top hats, striped trouser cutaway coats parade out to the burrow that houses Punxsu Phil.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Looks like they're starting. Roll tape.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Rolling. Rita silently counts down from five and cues Phil who ins snaps into announce mode.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to camera) Once a year, the eyes of the nation turn here, to this tiny hamlet in Pennsylvania, to watch a master at work. The master? Punxsutawney Phil, the world's most famous weatherman, the groundhog, who, as legend has it, can predict the coming of an early spring. Rita turns to Larry. This is impressive-- so far, so good A Groundhog Club Official kneels at the burrow and ceremoniously knocks on the small wooden door, then opens and retreats.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: And here's the big moment we've all been waiting for. Let's just see what Mr. Groundhog has to say. The groundhog sticks his head out, looks around, steps ou the hole, and runs over to the other side of the mound, a as far away from the cameras as he can get.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hey! Over here, you little weasel! Larry zooms in as far as he can but the best he can manag a close-up of the groundhog's back. The groundhog stands a moment, his body casting a long shadow, then he lets ou squeak and runs back into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Great shot, huh, folks? Well, that was certainly worth the trip. Now we'll be hearing from Mr. Buster Greene, President of the Punxsutawney Groundhog Club, the so-called Seer of Seers who will interpret for us. BUSTER GREENE, dressed up in his top hat and cutaway coat walks onto the mound and hushes the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: B U ST E R
dialogues.text: He came out, and he saw his shadow. Sorry, ladies and gentlemen, but it looks like it's going to be a long winter. The crowd lets out a good-natured "Awwwwww" in disappoint

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (sarcastic, to camera) Well, that's it. Sorry you couldn't be here in person to share the electric moment. This is one event where televison really fails to capture the excitement of thousands of people gathered to watch a large squirrel predict the weather, and I for one am deeply grateful to have been a part of it. Reporting for Channel 9, this is Phil Connors. Larry cuts the camera.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (to Phil) You want to try one that's a little sweeter?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to Rita) That's as sweet as I get. I'm outa here. As he exits, Phil tosses the mike to Larry, who isn't exp the throw and bobbles it, dropping the mike on the ground

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (MUTTERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prima donnas.

dialogues.speaker: INT . DINER
dialogues.text: Phil is sitting alone having a cup of coffee in a busy, l and lively cafe. Rita enters, sees him sitting there, cro to his table and sits down across from him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That was really lousy.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Is it my fault the little rat went south on us?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: A real professional would have handled it. You acted like it was a personal insult. Who do you think you are -- Wolf Blitzer?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: God, you really take this stuff seriously, don't you.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. As far as I ' m concerned there are no little stories, Phil. Only little reporters with big egos who think they're too good for the job they have to do.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (trying to look hurt) You really don't know me very well, do you. 'Cause if you did you could never say something like that about me. I care! Call me a cockeyed optimist but I happen to think there's more to this job than just getting my ugly mug on the boob tube every night.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Is that so.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yes, that is so. Rita is so irritated by him she can't even respond. Phil looks at her evenly for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So as far as us getting together, would you say the glass is half empty or half full? Larry pokes his head in the doorway, looks around, spots and makes his way over to their table.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to Rita) You ready? We better get going if we ' re going to stay ahead of the weather.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You don't have to rush off, you know. That storm is 'going to miss us completely.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Nice working with you, Phil. See you around. Rita walks away, leaving him sitting alone.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: В«

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil's Lexus is driving down the highway. Light snow is j starting to fall.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (V.O)
dialogues.text: (on the earphone) I'll call you after I see the network guy. I should be back there in a couple of hours...What?...1 can't hear you-- you're breaking up...Hello? Sabrina?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is getting annoyed as the phone connection deteriora The snow is getting heavier. Phil switches on the windshi wipers.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Sabrina ? Can you hear me? Shit! He slams the phone back into it's cradle, then looks up a notices slow traffic up ahead. He honks his horn as the traffic comes to a complete stop. He keeps honking but no moves. He rolls down the window and looks up ahead. The highway parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No. No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil jumps out and begins to walk down the highway, past parked cars, shivering in his light sweater and silk spor shirt. The snowfall is getting heavier and the wind is pi up. The snow comes down unnaturally hard and fast. He wal on, slipping and sliding in his expensive loafers until h j comes to a police roadblock up ahead, manned by TWO HIG "J PATROLMEN.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What's going on, Officer?

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Nothin's goin1 on. We're closin1 the road. Big accident up ahead. Blizzard movin1 in.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What blizzard? A couple of flakes! An isolated phenomenon of nature.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Are you nuts? We got a major storm movin' in.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, no. All that moisture is going to miss us and hit Harrisburg.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Pal, you got that moisture on your head.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: But I have to get to Pittsburgh today!

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Mister, the only place anybody's goin' on this road is back to Punxsutawney. Phil glowers at him and shivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is on a pay phone. Snow is falling heavily outside. GAS STATION ATTENDANT is shovelling around the pumps.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So all the long distance lines a re down? What about the sa tellite? Is it snowing in space?...But I have to call Pittsburgh...Isn't there some special line you keep open for emergencies or for celebrities?...Well, I'm both really. I'm a celebrity in an emergency. Can you patch me through on that line?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Phil is blasted with frigid Arctic win blowing snow. The GAS STATION ATTENDANT enters the tiny o and in trying to squeeze past Phil accidentally bangs him the head with his snow shovel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is at the bar in Punxsutawney ' s oldest and best ho Pennsylvanian. He looks very bored, drinking a beer, unsuccessfully hustling an attractive local girl named NA

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You never saw me on TV-- on the news?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don't think so. What part of the news do you do?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I ' m the White House correspondent for NBC news.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh , I ' m so sure .

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Ask me anything?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Okay, how big is the White House?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Three bedrooms, two and a half baths. Looks much bigger than it , is. Nancy just stares at him, clearly not into his sense of h Suddenly, a BRIDE in full white wedding gown and veil rus into the bar, crying and shouting. A gaggle of BRIDESMAID flutters around her trying to coax her back to her own we but she won't budge. Then the GROOM, wearing a bad rented comes storming in and tries to drag her back, until the B MAN restrains him and the bridesmaids hustle the bride aw Phil watches the whole drama play out, then turns back to Nancy .

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Good start. I ' m sure they'll be very happy. So what do you say? You want to play doggie obedience school with me?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'll pass. She gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Sit! Stay! He watches her go, then tosses a tip on the bar and exits somewhat unsteadily.

dialogues.speaker: A THICK BOOK
dialogues.text: The cover reads "101 Curses, Spells and Enchantments You at Home." A well-manicured feminine hand opens the book t marked page .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil enters his room and drunkenly tosses his overcoat, s and gloves on the floor in a heap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie Decastro, Phil ' s disaffected ex-lover, is sit cross-legged on the floor with the book of curses open in of her. Her hair is down, she's wearing a caftan with a Z print, there are candles everywhere and other vaguely occ decorating touches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil's business card is dropped into a dish. Then the Tar card of the Hanged Man, a chicken bone, and a feather are placed on top of it .

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: He stands at the sink, looking at himself in the mirror, flexing his muscles .

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Reading from the book> she mutters incantations in a s language, then she sprinkles some powder on the plate, th few drops of oil. Then she makes a few passes over it wit hands and, much to her surprise, the contents of the plat spontaneously combust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he crosses to the bed, he accidentally knocks over the suitcase stand, spilling his clothes out onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He contemplates picking them up for a moment, decides to them there, and flops down on the bed. He lies there look u up at the ceiling until the room starts to spin around, he closes his eyes and quickly drops off to sleep, still clothed.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: To complete the spell, she picks up a broken wristwatch a drops it into the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil's business card, the Hanged Man and the broken watch flames. The watch crystal is cracked and the hands are fr at 5:59.

dialogues.speaker: C LOSE UP
dialogues.text: The digital clock-radio changes from 5:59 to 6:00 AM. The radio comes on, playing the end of the Sonny and Cher hit Got You, Babe," just as it did the day before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil sits up in bed, quickly alert, and looks around the Something is wrong. He's wearing pajamas, his suit is onc again hanging neatly on the closet door and his suitcase back on its stand at the foot of the bed, again neatly pa The song ends and the same radio deejay and his sidekick on with the same manic energy. Phil stares at the radio a listens to them. A look of astonishment comes over his fa they banter.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: Okay, campers, rise and shine, and don't forget your booties because it's COOOLD out there today!

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: It's cold out there everyday. What is this-- Miami Beach? The deejay laughs. Phil "mock" laughs at exactly the same time, recognizing the repartee from the previous morning.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to himself) Nice going guys. That's yesterday's tape. Phil crosses to the sink and gets a towel off the rack, o half-listening to the radio.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: Not hardly. Expect hazardous travel later today with that, you know, blizzard thing --

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: That "blizzard thing?" Phil turns on the water and splashes some on his face as trying to wake himself up, vaguely disturbed by the repet of the broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Oh, here's the report: the National Weather Service is calling for a big blizzard thing."

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: Yes they are, but there's another reason today is very special --

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: Especially cold --

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: Especially cold, okay, but the big question on everybody's lips -- Phil supplies the next line in unison with the radio.

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK AND PHIL
dialogues.text: Chapped lips --

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: -- on their chapped lips, right -- Do you think Phil's going to come out and see his shadow?

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: Punxsutawney Phil. Some vague doubt causes Phil to go to the window.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: That's right, rodent lovers!

dialogues.speaker: BOTH DEEJAYS
dialogues.text: Groundhog Day! SOUND EFFECT of GRUNTING GROUNDHOGS as Phil pulls back th curtains and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is full of people heading toward Gobbler's Kno exactly as they did the day before.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (AGHAST)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: INT. BED AND BREAKFAST
dialogues.text: Phil rushes out into the corridor, hastily tying his tie, suit jacket and overcoat over his arm. As he heads for th breakfast room, the same Chubby Man passes.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY MAN
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY MAN
dialogues.text: Think it'll be an early Spring?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (stops, irritated) Didn't we do this yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY MAN
dialogues.text: (INTIMIDATED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean. Phil grabs him by the front of his shirt and looks deep i his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Don't mess with me, pork chop. What day is this?

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY MAN
dialogues.text: (TERRIFIED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Febr uary second--Groundhog Day! Phil can see he's telling the truth and relaxes his grip poor man.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Okay. Sorry. I'm having a bad day. Phil walks on, leaving the chubby man baffled and insulte

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY MAN
dialogues.text: (to himself) I'll say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil enters the old library of the house and finds everyt exactly as it was the day before. Mrs. Lancaster spots Ph she comes out of the kitchen with the fresh pot of coffee

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: Did you sleep well, Mr. Connors?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (completely confused) D i d I? I don't know--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: Would you like some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you. I ' m feeling a little strange.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: ( as she pours) I wonder what the weather's going to be like for all the festivities.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Did you ever have deja vu, Mrs. Lancaster?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: Is that the Italian dessert with the brandy and the chocolate mousse?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, that's spaghetti. Never mind. He heads for the door, still in a daze.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: Oh, will you be checking out today, Mr. Connors?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (VAGUELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't think so. I'll tell you after I wake up. Phil exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil gulps down the steaming coffee, still trying to wake from what he assumes is a dream, and descends the front s of the house. He accosts a PASSERBY.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Ma'am? Excuse me. Where's everybody going?

dialogues.speaker: PASSERBY
dialogues.text: To Gobbler's Knob. It's Groundhog Day! The coffee cup drops from Phil's hand as he stands there mouthed. Then he slaps his own face and shakes his head a trying to clear it and starts off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil rushes down the street, again failing to notice the BUM sitting on the sidewalk leaning against a storefront.

dialogues.speaker: NED RYERSON, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Phil! Ned Ryerson approaches with the same obnoxious attitude.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Phil! Phil Connors! I thought that was you! Phil just stares at him and keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: My oh my! Phil Connors. Don't say you don't remember me, 'cause I sure as heck-fire remember you. Well?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Ned Ryerson?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Bing! First shot right out of the box. So how's it going, ol' buddy?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: To tell you the truth, Neddy, I ' m not feeling real well. Could you excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Now it's funny you should mention your health 'cause you'll never guess what I do.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (very distressed and desperate to get away from this guy) Do you sell insurance, Ned?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Bing again! You're sharp as a tack today. Do you have life insurance, Phil? 'Cause if you do, I bet you could use more -- who couldn't?" -- but I got a feeling you don't have any. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (really annoyed now) Did I say "fuck off, " Ned? I can't talk to you right now. He backs away from Ned and steps right into the same deep slushy puddle he stepped in the day before.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (BRAYING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look .out for that first v step. It's a doozyi Phil looks down at his wet shoes and cuffs and stumbles o toward Gobbler's Knob.

dialogues.speaker: EXT . GOBBLER ' S KNOB
dialogues.text: The crowd is gathered as before for the big moment. In the press area, Rita is having the same dialogue with when she spots Phil heading into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Here he comes. Phill Hey, Phil! Over here! Phil waves to her and heads straight for an obscure corne the Knob, gesturing for her to follow. Larry shakes his head as Rita charges through the crowd t Phil. She catches up to him just as he is scratching a ma the snow with his foot. She notices immediately that he i uncharacteristically dishevelled, his tie askew, his hair mussed.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Where ' ve you been?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (nervous, sweat ing) I've got to talk to you. I think I'm losing my mind.

dialogues.speaker: . RITA
dialogues.text: I know you're losing it. What are you doing over here? The camera's over there.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Slap me, Rita.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (INSISTENT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just slap me-- hard. She gives up and taps him lightly on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I said hardl . . .. ... .RITA . I can't!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Do it! Rita shrugs and slaps him very hard.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (his cheek smarting) Better. Almost too hard, Rita.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Are you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, drunk is more fun. Can I be serious with you for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don't know. Can you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yes. I ' m being serious. I' m having a problem-- no, I may be having a problem.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What are you trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'm trying to say that if I was having a problem, just hypothetical ly, I ' d like to know that you're someone I could count on in a crisis.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (WORRIED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do last night? The crowd begins to hush.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: We better get started. We're going to miss it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Were not going to miss it. (indicating the other

dialogues.speaker: REPORTERS
dialogues.text: They're going to miss it.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (EMPHATIC)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil. We've been out here for an hour. We're cold and tired. Let's just get this and get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Okay, put it here.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Put the camera here . Rita takes a forlorn glance towards the press area, where of the other cameras are set up .

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Phil , there is no tomorrow on this one. It's Groundhog Day.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: We were in the wrong spot yesterday .

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (IRKED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W ha t? Yesterday? What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Just trust me. Put the camera here .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita looks at him like he's crazy, then looks at her watc gives up.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Larry! She charges off toward the cameras. In the Press Area, several reporters are already talking their cameras, dribbling on about how "He could appear an second now." Rita and Larry grab their gear and rush back Phil. Larry hurriedly sets up the camera.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You want me to roll tape?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (to Phil) Are you going to get on your mark?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No hurry. Larry glances over at the other news reporters, all talki their cameras and pointing towards the mound.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (DESPERATELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone else is rolling! Rita looks helplessly at Phil.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I'm begging you, all right? Gould we please just do this? Phil glances down at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Okay, let's do it. He crosses over to Larry and taps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Roll tape.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (MUMBLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prima donnas. Phil takes the microphone from Rita and positions himself against the fence.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Rolling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil does a similar intro to the one he did before, thoug time it's a bit tentative.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to camera) We ll, it's Groundhog Day-- again-- and you know what that means. Everybody's here on Gobbler's Knob waiting in the cold for the appearance of the most famous groundhog in the world, Punxsutawney Phil, who's going to tell us just how much more of this we can expect. The Groundhog Club Official knocks on the groundhog's doo then opens it and retreats. Phil takes a deep breath and makes his first experimental prediction, recalling the previous day.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: My forecast is we're going to see the groundhog peek its head out of its hole, look around a little bit, then he's going to come out, scamper over to this general area, look at the crowd for a second, make a little burping noise and run back into the ground.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (whispers to Larry) That's it. I'm going to kill him. Phil looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: O k ay ? And here we go-- Phil points to the hole and Larry zooms in. The groundhog sticks his head out, looks left, looks righ steps out of the hole, and runs away from the press pool, directly over to Larry's camera. As he stands there, his casts a long shadow. The groundhog looks right into the camera, lets out a squeak, and runs back into the hole. Rita and Larry are completely amazed as the crowd cheers brief appearance of the groundhog. Larry pans back to Phi Phil just stands there speechless, staring at the groundh burrow.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (HISSES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil! Buster Greene, the Groundhog club official, walks onto th mound and hushes the crowd, exactly as before.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: He came out, and he saw his shadow. Sorry, ladies and gentlemen, but it looks like it's going to be a long winter. Again the crowd lets out a good-natured "Awwwwww" in disappointment. Larry pans back to Phil just in time to see him walking a a fog, without signing off. Then he pans back to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (at a loss) For Channel 9 News, this is Rita Hanson in Punxsutawney. She holds for a moment then makes the cut sign, drawing h finger across her throat.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Phil is on the phone desperately trying to make a call.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (on the phone) I know there's a blizzard, but I have to get a call through to my doctor in Pittsburgh. It's a medical emergency. . . .No, don't give me the Punxsutawney Fire Department. When do you think the long distance lines will be working again?. . . But what if we don't have a tomorrow? We didn't have one today, my friend... Hello...Hello? He hangs up and shakes his head which is now really start ache, then he pops a handful of Tylenol, lies down and pu the covers up over his head. A moment later, he sits up, a pencil from the nightstand, breaks it in half and puts pieces back on the nightstand. Then he lies back down and retreats back under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The digital clock-radio changes from 5:59 to 6:00 AM. The radio comes on, playing the end of the Sonny and Cher hit Got You, Babe," just as it did the day before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil sits up in bed fearing the worst and looks on the nightstand. The pencil is whole again. Completely stunned the phenomenon, he jumps out of bed and starts dressing hurriedly as the morning Deejays begin their now familiar

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: Okay, campers, rise and shine, and don't forget your booties because it's COOOLD out there today!

dialogues.speaker: SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: It's cold out there everyday. What is this-- Miami Beach? Phil rushes out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil hurries toward the bed and breakfast carrying two ga buckets of paint, and a couple of big bags from a hardwar store.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BED AND BREAKFAST
dialogues.text: Phil enters and passes Mrs. Lancaster in the breakfast ro

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: Painting something, Mr. Connors?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I ' m conducting an experiment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil enters and dumps the bags on the bed. Out fall a cou of big paintbrushes, a small sledgehammer, a handsaw, a crowbar, plastic goggles and assorted other tools. He put the goggles, grabs a hammer and some nails and starts nai the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lancaster and several other guests are gathered in t hall outside Phil's room, listening at the door and looki very worried. Loud music is playing inside the room. From inside the room, they hear the sound of loud hammeri wood splintering and glass breaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil, has demolished just about all the furniture and woo in the room. He rips off the last of the wooden moldings the crowbar, then crosses to the mirror over the demolish sink. Phil stands there, staring at his image in the mirror, tr to figure out what's happening to him. He starts breathin heavier, as if gathering courage, then, just when we thin going to cut off his ear or something, he raises an elect barber clipper and shaves a bald stripe up the middle of head. He studies his new look for a moment then smashes t mirror with his sledgehammer. Then he opens the cans of paint, dips the two big brushes the cans and starts slapping bright red paint onto the wa madly, feverishly, splashing himself and everything else room with it. As a final touch he grabs the bed pillows and rips them o then shakes them all around the room creating a storm of feathers. Finally, Phil falls exhausted on the bed. From outside we hear outraged hotel employees pounding on the door. We pan over to the clock radio, the only undamaged object the room. Feathers drift down past the face of the clock reads 5:59 AM. The time changes to 6:00, the radio clicks and "I Got You, Babe" starts playing as we pan back to Ph sleeping on the bed. He opens his eyes, jumps out of bed and looks around. No paint, no feathers, no damage. Everything is as clean and as the day he checked in. He races over to the unbroken mirror and looks at himself hair is completely restored, as if it had never been shav The song ends and the deejays come on. Phil says every wo right along with them, shocked into a state of complete wonderment.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL AND DEEJAY
dialogues.text: Okay, campers, rise and shine, and don't forget your booties because it's COOOLD out there today.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL AND SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: It's cold out there everyday. What is this -- Miami Beach? The deejay laughs. Phil laughs insanely along with him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT . GOBBLER ' S KNOB
dialogues.text: Phil is wrapping up another groundhog report, trying to b completely professional despite the circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (with forced good

dialogues.speaker: HUMOR
dialogues.text: . . . S o according to Mr. Groundhog I guess we can expect six more weeks of winter. It's not very scientific, but it sure is fun. Hey, wait a second. If he's right, I could be out of a job! (mock laugh) For Channel 9 News, this is Phil Connors in Punxsutawney . He holds until Larry stops tape, then approaches Rita.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: How was that?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (PLEASED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was good. A little smarmy for my taste, but I guess that's what sells.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Could I talk to you about a matter that is not work related?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You never talk about work.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Do you know what I did last night?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Do I want to know?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I destroyed my hotel room.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You whatl This is not some kind of rock and roll tour. We don't have the budget for that--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, it's okay. This morning it was all right again. That's what I have to talk to you about.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Phil, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Rita cross the street and walk past a crowd of concerned citizens gathered around what looks like a car accident. As an ambulance arrives, Phil and Rita enter th cozy looking diner on the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Rita sit together at the same table they had previously. The WAITER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (to waiter) Could I have some coffee, please? The waiter pours her a cup.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (EXITING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back to take your order.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Thanks. (to Phil) Okay, so tell me. How'd you know where to put the camera?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Because I've done it before.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I know, but the groundhog doesn't do exactly the same thing every year, does he?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I ' m not talking about last year. I ' m talking about today. I lived it before.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You're having deja vu?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Big time. Rita, I know it's nuts but I keep reliving the same day o ve r and over-- Groundhog Day-- today. This is the third time.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (completely skeptical) Uh-huh. I'm waiting for the punchline.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, really. It's like today never happened. I shaved my head last night, today its all grown back. I could probably cut off my limbs, one by one, and - pop! They'd grow back. Just like a starfish. I probably don't even have to floss?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I'm wracking my brain, but I can't even begin to imagine why you'd make up something like this.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: 'Cause I'm not making it up. I'm asking for your help. Rita looks at him for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll bite. What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: The truth? I'd 1ike you to spend the next 24 hours with me and don't leave my side for a second.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I see. You know, Phil, you can charm all the little P.A.'s at the station, all the secretaries, and even some of the weekend a nchors, but not me-- not in a thousand years.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Wa it a second--

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Not if I was dying and your breath was the only cure; not if having your child was the only way to preserve the human race. Just get it out of your head because it is NOT GOING TO

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So much for the truth. Larry pokes his head in the doorway, looks around, spots and makes his way over to their table.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to Rita) You ready? We better get going if we're going to stay ahead of the weather.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yeah, , I ' m . ready, Larry. (EXITING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: X-rays of Phil's skull are slapped up onto a light box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is having his head examined by a NEUROLOGIST.

dialogues.speaker: NEUROLOGIST
dialogues.text: No spots, no tumors, no lesions, no clots, no aneurisms. Everything looks fine and dandy to me, Mr. Connors. Have you considered psychiatric help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punxsutawney's only PSYCHOLOGIST is a marriage and family counselor at the local Lutheran church. His appearance an manner indicate he may have some serious problems of his

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: (not too confident) That's kind of an unusual problem, Mr. Connors. Most of my work is with couples and families. Phil is lying on a couch. His head is completely shaved.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you're still a psychologist. You must have had some course in school that covered this kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Sort of, I guess. Abnormal Psychology.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So based on that what would you say?

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: (HESITANT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ' d say that maybe you're -- I don't know -- a little delusional.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You're saying this thing is not really happening to me?

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Then how do I know this conversation is really happening?

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: I guess you don't.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Then forget about me paying you. A discreet little alarm sounds.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: (RELIEVED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that's all the time we have, Mr. Connors.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Wait! Are you saying I'm crazy?

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: (humoring him) Not necessarily. If it concerns you we should schedule our next session as soon as possible. How's tomorrow for you? Phil glowers at him.

dialogues.speaker: A MODEL OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM
dialogues.text: A SCIENTIST in a white lab coat is holding up the model. looks on with interest.

dialogues.speaker: SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: (AUTHORITATIVELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now if the moon exerts a gravitational pull strong enough to cause the tides, .then it may be theoretically possible for a Black Hole or a Singularity of sufficient magnitude to actually bend time enough to cause it to fold back ,on itself.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You think that's a realistic possibility? A paper airplane sails past his head, accompanied by a no outburst of juvenile laughter. We pull back to REVEAL:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five eighth-graders running amok.

dialogues.speaker: SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: (STERNLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! I think someone may just need a little visit to the Assistant Principal's office! Get back in your seats. The bell has not rung yet. The kids sit back down, but keep up their noisy chatter.

dialogues.speaker: SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: (to Phil) Well, I ' m speaking purely hypothetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is walking toward the exit when he passes a first gr classroom. The door is open and the TEACHER is discussing story with the class.

dialogues.speaker: TEACH ER
dialogues.text: So the princess picked up the frog and kissed him. Phil stops outside the door to listen.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Now who can tell me what happened when the princess kissed the frog.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOY
dialogues.text: Her lips got slimed! The whole class erupts in giggles and shrieks.

dialogues.speaker: T EACHER
dialogues.text: Okay, come on now. What happened when she kissed the frog?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: The princess kissed the frog and the spell got broke and he turned into a handsome prince and they got married and lived happily ever after.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is leaning against the wall listening. There is some very arresting about the fairy tale, but finally he just his head and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is at a bar getting drunk with two local blue-collar workers, GUS and PHIL.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Gus, what would you do if there was no tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You mean like if the world was gonna end?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, I mean like if it was never going to end. If everyday was the same and you were stuck here and you couldn't get out and nothing you did mattered?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You're right. Everyday is the same, I can't get out of here and nothin' I do matters.

dialogues.speaker: V RALPH
dialogues.text: No, he's askin1 you a question, ya idiot.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: What was the question?

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: What if nothing mattered?! Jeez, I know what I'd do. I ' d j ust spend all my time drivin' fast, gettin1 loaded and gettin' laid. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: That's it. It just doesn't get any better than this, does it? Good friends, good conversation and quality brew. Drink up, boys. They salute each other and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil, Gus and Ralph approach Ralph's big, black, old Buic convertible parked outside the bar. They are even drunker they were before.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: (fumbling with his

dialogues.speaker: CARKEYS
dialogues.text: Where you stayin', Phil? We'll drop you off.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hey, friends don't let friends drive drunk. Give me your keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's as wasted as they are, but Ralph hands over his keys without a fight.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Thanks , man .

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: It's nothing. Get in. They all pile into the front seat with Phil at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (starting the ear) Seatbelts. Ralph and Gus give him the thumbs up sign and start diggi around in the seat cracks for their seatbelts. Suddenly, floors the accelerator and peels away, sideswiping a park as he screeches around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is having a great time. Gus and Ralph are whooping i like kids on a roller coaster.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: This is great, Ralph!

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, take a left! Phil passes the intersection.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: You missed it!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No problem --

dialogues.speaker: EXT . MAIN STREET
dialogues.text: Phil throws the car into a high-speed, skidding U-turn, g on the curb, across a couple of lawns, takes out a mailbo a STOP sign and bounces back onto the street. A POLICE CAR parked in front of the hardware store pulls and takes off after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil swerves in and out of oncoming traffic. Gus is start to look a little green.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So many rules --

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: You can say that again.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: "Don't do this--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Buick demolishes a parked car.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Don't do that -- " He mows down a row of parking meters.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CAR
dialogues.text: It comes screaming around a corner in hot pursuit of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph hears the siren and looks back at the police car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! Try and stop us, you mothers !

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No more rules!

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: No more rules!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second police car joins the chase.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: (looking back) That's two!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Having a good time?

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: I'm having a great time! Phil speeds up to a hundred miles and hour. Gus is lookin even worse from the liquor and the motion of the car.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Hey, uh --

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Phil.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Yeah, Phil-- like the groundhog.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Hey, Phil? How're we going to get out of this?

dialogues.speaker: THE INTERSECTION AHEAD
dialogues.text: Two police cars with lights flashing are parked sideways, completely blocking the road. Officers stand in the roadw motioning for Phil to stop.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (CALMLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus, you're just going to have to trust me on this one. He tromps the gas pedal to the floor. Gus's eyes go wide terror. The police dive out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL AND RALPH
dialogues.text: Yahooooo!

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: The Buick crashes head on into one of the police cars.

dialogues.speaker: C LOSE UP
dialogues.text: The time changes from 5:59 to 6:00. The radio starts play "I Got You, Babe." Phil sits up suddenly and looks around, completely amazed is in his room at the bed and breakfast, everything exact same as before. He hops out of bed and quickly examines himself for signs of physical injury. Nothing. The music and the two deej ays come on.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY
dialogues.text: Okay, campers, rise and shine, and don't forget your booties because it's COOOLD out there today. Phil talks out loud along with them.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL AND SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: It's cold out there everyday. What is this-- Miami Beach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deejays laughs. Phil laughs, too, exhilirated at havi survived the car wreck, still very confused and perplexed just beginning to see the possibilities of his unique situation. He starts dressing in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil rushes into the breakfast room just as Mrs. Lancaste comes out of the kitchen with the coffee. Everything is exactly the same as before.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: W o u l d you-- Phil interrupts, answering all her questions before she e asks them.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (URGENTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I would like some coffee; the weather is going to be cold and overcast with blizzard conditions moving in later today; and yes, I will be staying an extra day.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: (BAFFLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lancaster, has anyone been around here looking for me this morning? Maybe a state official, blue coat, hat, gun, nightstick, badge, driving a late-model Ford br Chevy, black and white with bub ble lights on top--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: (SHOCKED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no one like that-- I .don't-- Will they be?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (greatly relieved) Apparently not. Phil gooses her, grabs a sweet roll, and heads for the do starting to believe now that he can truly do anything he to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil stops on the steps, puts on his coat and gloves and joins the traffic heading toward Gobbler's Knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil passes the old bum, ignoring him as usual.

dialogues.speaker: NED, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Phil! Phil slips off his glove as Ned Ryerson lumbers toward hi

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Phil! Phil Connors!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Ned! Ned Ryerson! Ned the Head! Before Ned can say another word, Phil SLUGS HIM. Ned goes down, Phil puts his glove back on and keeps walking. Phil deftly avoids the slushy pothole he stepped in befor PEDESTRIAN walking behind him steps right into it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT . GOBBLER'S KNOB
dialogues.text: Phil is passing through the crowd on his way to the press when he notices NANCY, the girl he met at the hotel bar, stops to talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You here to see the groundhog? She gives him a look. It's obvious she's never seen him before.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Can you think of another reason anybody'd be out here at dawn on a freezing day?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Nancy Taylor. And you are--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Where'd you go to high school?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (PLAYFUL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High school? She really doesn't know what to make of Phil but she deci play along.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Lincoln High school. In Pittsburgh. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Who was your twelfth grade English teacher?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'm waiting.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: .Mrs. Walsh.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Walsh. Nancy, Lincoln, Walsh.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Is this some kind of come-on?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'm not really sure. We'll have to see. Phil walks off and joins Rita at their camera position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is sitting at his usual table, which is covered with incredible variety of rich foods-- eggs, bacon, sausage, pancakes, pies, cakes, eclairs, ice cream, puddings, etc. Rita sits across from him, watching in amazement as he st himself with pastry.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Is this some new fad diet? Don't you worry about cholesterol? Phil scrapes a plate and takes a final bite of a chocolat eclair.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I don't worry about anything anymore.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What makes you so special? Everybody worries about something.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: That's exactly what makes me so special. He takes a big bite of cake. Rita shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (with his mouth full) What?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: "The wretch, concentered all in self, Living, shall forfeit fair renown, And doubly dying, shall go down to the vile dust from whence he sprung, Unwept, unhonored, and unsung." Sir Walter Scott.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (stares at her for a long moment) "There was a young man from Na n t uc k e t-- "

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That's really funny. When are you going to grow up, Phil?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: At this rate-- never. (he pulls out a pack of

dialogues.speaker: CIGARETTES
dialogues.text: Okay if I smoke? Rita shrugs. Phil lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You really do have a death wish, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Just the opposite, Rita. I have a life wish. I'm just trying to enjoy it. Taking pleasure in the little things. Don't you ever just want to cut loose and go wild?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I wouldn't even know what it means to go wild.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, that's where I come in. Going wild is one of my specialties. Last night I got completely loaded and drove head- on into a police car.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (DISBELIEVING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really? You look pretty good this morning.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: That's my point. I know you won't believe me, but we could do anything we want today and it wouldn't matter one bit. Absolutely no consequences. Complete and total freedom.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: And how. . , do we manage that?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You leave that to me. Why don't you send Larry back and hang out with me for the rest of the day? You never make it through that blizzard anyway. Larry enters the diner and spots them.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I'll take my chances with the -weather. But you have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I plan to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil comes through the crowd and finds Nancy in the same she was in the day before.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Nancy? Nancy turns and looks at him quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Nancy, right?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Nancy Taylor? Lincoln High? I sat next to you in Mrs. Walsh's English class.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: T h at --

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Phil Connors.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: --is amazing!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You don't remember me, do you?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don't-- sure, I think--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: We used to shoot spit balls--

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yeah, oh, God--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I even asked you to the prom.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Phil Connors.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: How ARE you?!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I ' m great. Wow, you look terrific. Hey, listen, I gotta d o this report--

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You're a reporter?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Weatherman. Channel 9, Pittsburgh.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Right, I should've known--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: But maybe after we could --

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I ' d like that --

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Phil! Rita is calling from across the crowd. She looks at him w disapproval .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is making passionate love to a WOMAN in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (MOANS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Phil.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh , Rita . The woman suddenly freezes. There is a moment of silence, she snaps on the light. It's Nancy, not Rita. Phil is as surprised as she is by his slip of the tongue.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (COLD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Rita?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (CAUGHT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one. It's just something I say when I make love. You know -- "Orita", "Orighta"-- it's like "Oh, baby" or something.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (not entirely

dialogues.speaker: CONVINCED
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (corrects her) O-rita. Nancy laughs uncertainly. Phil switches off the light, thinking now about Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
