dialogues.text: Some elderly GUESTS are sipping coffee and eating breakfa staring uncomfortably at something on the other side of t room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is standing at the bookcase, wearing only pajamas, absently munching on a Danish as he reads from one of the books. Mrs. Lancaster approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: Isn't it a wonderful collection?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Yes, it is. You don't usually find this many trashy novels in one place.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: You can take a book up to your room if you like.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I've actually read them all. I was just rereading some of the dirty parts. He finishes and puts the book back on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: (WORRIED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will you be staying with us, Mr. Connors?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Indefinitely. I've already been here for 211 days.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LANCASTER
dialogues.text: (humoring him) Really? That's quite a long time, isn't it. I hope you're finding things to do in our little town.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (CASUALLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, I'm getting a little tired of casual sex so today I thought I'd rob a bank and buy myself a really expensive car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil kisses her on the lips and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two harmless-looking old GUARDS are calmly loading bags o into an armored car parked in front of a local bank. Sudd Phil appears, wielding a shotgun, wearing a Batman style his face completely hidden by a ski mask.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (SHOUTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, freeze!! Drop your guns J! The guards stand there frozen with terror.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You guys ever been held up before? (they shake their

dialogues.speaker: HEADS
dialogues.text: It's kind of exciting, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST GUARD
dialogues.text: (FRIGHTENED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so. Something to tell the kids about.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah. By the way, I'm Phil. He raises the mask and shows his face.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST GUARD
dialogues.text: Herman.

dialogues.speaker: S E C O N D GUARD
dialogues.text: Felix.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (shaking their hands) Herman and Felix. Okay. Take it easy, boys. And thanks. The frightened guards watch as Phil makes off with two la satchels of cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil pats the hood of a used BMW 850 sports car as a SALE stands by beaming. Phil is wearing a full Steelers footba uniform complete with shoulder pads.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: A real beauty, huh. We picked it u p at a--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'll take it. How much?

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Well, the sticker says $62,999 bu t if you want--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what. I'll give you $70,000 if you just knock off the car salesman stuff and let me get out of here with my car. The Salesman gawks as Phil opens his briefcase and starts counting out stacks of bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a high angle, we see the BMW tearing around the stre the town as if running a Grand Prix road race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BMW comes screeching to a stop right in front of the theater and the door opens. A pair of really elaborate cowboy boots complete with sil spurs hits the pavement first; then we PAN UP to see Phil emerge from the car wearing a really gaudy; full cowboy o with real six-guns on his hips. A very trashy-looking gir LARAINE, gets out on the passenger side, dressed like a F maid.

dialogues.speaker: LARAINE
dialogues.text: (very self-conscious) I thought we were going to a costume party.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, we are, we are. But first I have this movie theater fantasy I want to talk to you about. He escorts her into the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is lying on the table, getting elaborately tattooed. Rita walks by, looks in the window and is shocked to see there. Phil waves at her and points to the colorful new heart pi by a bloody dagger being tattooed on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan down the line of ROUGH TRADE PATRONS to. Phil, dre all in black leathers, both arms heavily tattooed, lookin Sid Viscious on crack. He takes off his hat to reveal red white and blue hair shaved almost down to his skull. A sl named ANGIE and another overweight, not very pretty MADON WANNA-BE, both in too-tight jeans and bullet bras are com to him, practically licking his ears. Angie pops a couple mystery pills into his mouth. Phil washes them down with shot and a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like ;outtakes from Fellini's "Satyricon." Heavy is blaring from the radio, as several unsavory looking me women are partying down, a few already passed out, sleepi whatever hit them. Someone is knocking loudly on the door shouting complaints about the music. A beer bottle smashe against the door. Phil is sitting up on the bed with Angie. He has his arm around her shoulder and a fifth of Wild Turkey in his han

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (more to himself than to Angie) Yeah, but eventually you' d just get tired of screwing around and then you'd want a real relationship, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: I don't know. A big German Shepherd tries to jump up on the bed with th

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Get down, Brunoi (CONTINUING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone decent, someone who you respected, who respects you.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: I guess so. The dog jumps up again.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Down , Bruno ! (still musing) It's tough to find a relationship like that, especially if your time is kind of limited. But you still have to try, don't you? (the dog again) Bruno! I told you! Off the bed! Phil looks over at Angle who's passed out with her mouth

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: There ' s got to be more to it than this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita is in the news van reviewing the tape of Phil's repo Phil hovers at the open side door.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You look good. I mean, it came o ut all right. How'd you know where to put the camera?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Psychic. So did you have a nice evening?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (GUARDED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just had a sandwich, watched some TV and went to bed.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I got my whole body tattooed and part ied all night with some nymphomaniac biker chicks.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (SKEPTICAL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds wholesome. Were those the new 24-hour disappearing tattoos or can I see them?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, they're gone. Rita, if you only had one day to live, what would you do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She switches off the videotape and steps out of the van.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don't know, Phil. What are you dying of?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, I mean like what if the entire world was about to explode?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I ' d just want to know where to p ut the camera. What are you looking for, Phil-- a date for the weekend? She starts walking toward the center of town. Phil sticks right with her.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, I just want to know you better. What do you like, what do you want, what do you think about, what kind of men are you interested in, what do you do for fun?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (she stops) Is this real or are you just going to make me feel like a fool?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to talk to you like a normal person. Isn't this how normal people talk?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Close.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Okay, so talk to me. C'mon, I'll buy you a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Rita are at their usual table, drinking coffee.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I guess I want what everybody wants-- you know, career, love, marriage, children. So far I don't have any of it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You have a career.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I have a job. Doing stories on the Punxsutawney groundhog is not my ultimate goal. No offense.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: How about the other stuff? You seeing anybody?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: This is getting too personal. I don't think I ' m ready to discuss these things with you. What about you? What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What I really want is someone like you.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: O h , please--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Phil, you know, you have so much talent and ability. If you'd just drop the attitude and act like a decent human being, then maybe I ' d -- (she hesitates)

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You'd what?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don't know what.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Then maybe you'd like me? She stares hard at him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's sort of like the way I feel about UFO's. I'd have to see it to believe it. Larry pokes his head in the doorway, looks around, spots and makes his way over to their table.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to Rita) You ready? We better get going if we're going to stay ahead of the weather.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll be right out, Larry. Larry scowls at Phil and exits.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to Rita) Why don't you stay for a while? The road's going to be closed anyway. Do you really want to be stuck in the van with Larry for three hours?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I've got to get back. I'll see you later. Phil watches Rita exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita gets in the news van and drives off with Larry. Phil stares out the window, more" determined than ever to her over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is wrapping up his groundhog report.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Well, you heard it right from the groundhog's mouth. Bundle up good, 'cause it's going to be a long winter-- at least in Punxsutawney. Reporting for Channel 9, this is Phil Connors. Larry stops tape.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That was great. How did you know

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (PREOCCUPIED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go now. There's something I have to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil runs off without another word of explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil has the hood open and is doing something to the engi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita is sitting at the bar in the town's best restaurant, good chophouse with Black Forest decor and waitresses dre in dirndl skirts and aprons. Phil enters and sits down ne her.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (acting surprised) Oh, hi, Rita. You still here?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (GLUM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van won't start. Larry's working on it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (INNOCENT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you know it. Buy you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Jack Daniels.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: For you, miss?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Tequila,with lime. Gold, if you've got it. Phil nods to himself.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Phil walks in and sits next to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (acting surprised) Oh, hi, Rita. You still here?

dialogues.speaker: R IT A
dialogues.text: (GLUM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van won't start. Larry's working on it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you know it. Buy you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Tequila with lime, gold if you've got it. Rita looks at Phil, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: For you miss?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Same for me, please. The BARTENDER pours.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to Rita) What should we toast to?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Your call.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: To the groundhog! Rita stares for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I always drink to world peace.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Take your order?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Tequila with lime, gold if you've got it. Rita looks at Phil.

dialogues.speaker: , BARTENDER
dialogues.text: For you, miss?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Same for me, please. The BARTENDER pours. Phil lifts his glass.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: To world peace. Rita smiles, reevaluating him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: To world peace. They clink glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita and Phil are now sitting together at a table, a plat cheese and crackers and a bottle of white wine between th

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You like your job?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It's okay. I think it could be really challenging. Of course it's about a million miles from where I started out in college.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You weren't in broadcasting?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: At Bryn Mawr? No, uh-uh. "Believe it or not, I studied Nineteenth Century French Poetry.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (laughs good-naturedly) Really? What a waste of time. Rita looks offended. Phil knows he made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You weren't in broadcasting?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: At Bryn Mawr? No, uh-uh. Believe it or not, I studied Nineteenth Century French Poetry. Phil leans in closer to her.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: La fille qui j'aimera Sera comme bon vin Qui se bonifiera Un peut chaque matin. Rita smiles, entranced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Rita are sitting at a table in a small confectio tasting chunks of different flavored fudge. Rita takes a

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: This is terrific.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Best fudge in town.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: How do you know so much about Punxsutawney?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I like small towns. I think they engender real community more than big cities.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That is so true! I've always thought that, too.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No kidding. Here-- try the white chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, yuk, don't make me sick.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (making mental note) No white chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: There's something so familiar about this. Do you ever have deja vu? Phil smiles. Then Larry enters.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (irate, to Rita) I don't believe it. Someone bought every distributor cap in this town. We're going to be stuck here all night1 Over Phil's sympathetic look we hear the song, "I Can't G Started With You".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music continues over Rita and Phil on the small dance floor. They dance, close, dreamy, romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a light snow falling. Phil and Rita are making a little snowman. Somehow the town looks magical tonight-- fashioned, wholesome. A snowball hits Phil in the back. He and Rita turn around see a giggling KID. Phil packs a snowball and tosses it. kid throws one back. Rita and Phil both get into it, pack snowballs and getting into a war with this kid and his li gang of friends. A snowball catches Rita unaware, she slips and goes down snowbank. Phil bends down to help her and slips. They are together, lying in the snow, laughing. Their eyes lock fo long sweet moment, then Rita gets embarrassed and stands

dialogues.speaker: EXT . CHERRY STREET INN
dialogues.text: Phil and Rita are walking slowly, very close.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I ' m just amazed. And I'm not easily amazed.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: How you can start a day with one kind of expectation and end up so completely different.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Do you like how this day is turning out?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yes. I like it very much. They stop dn front of Phil's hotel. She turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You could never have planned a day like this, but it couldn't have been more perfect.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You're wrong. I've been planning this day for weeks. Rita ignores the remark and hugs him. Phil tries to kiss but she gently puts her fingers to his lips, stopping him \ They enter the bed and breakfast inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita hugs him again and starts to exit.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Thanks. See you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Tomorrow? Wait, aren't you going to come up to my room for a while?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (very reluctant) I don't know, Phil--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: NoВ·reason to end a perfect day.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (DECIDING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well-- we better not.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, you should. The, uh, the poetry! I've got some books, Rimbaud, Beaudelaire, we could l ig ht a fire--

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Thanks, but --

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (seeing it all slip

dialogues.speaker: AWAY
dialogues.text: Please come, Rita. It'll be --

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (DEFINITE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil, I'm tired. We can be together tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (getting desperate) But there is no tomorrow for me!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (ADAMANT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not ruin it, Phil. There's no way I ' m sleeping with you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Why not? Rita, I love you!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You don't even know me!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (grabs her hand) Please! You have to! Rita shakes loose from his grasp.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you! There is a long moment of silent tension, then all her ol doubts about Phil come rushing back.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) Oh, no. I can't believe I fell for it. This whole day was just one long set-up. And I ate fudge. Yucchh! I hate fudge.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, it was real. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Stop saying that! Do you really expect me to trust you? The whole secretarial pool is a Phil Connors recovery group.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: But I can change! I really can-- Rita slaps him hard on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That's for making me care about you. She turns and stomps off, leaving Phil standing there hur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snowball fight with the kids is going on as before. P falls into the snowbank with Rita and they almost kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is trying (MOS) to talk his way into Rita's room. Sh ^pushes him away and slams the door in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The streets are deserted except for Phil, staring up at R window in the Quality Inn. Rita comes to her window and looks out. She sees Phil loo up at her and draws the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I Got You, Babe" is playing. Phil hits the clock radio t turn it off. He lies there for a moment, then hefts himse heavily out of bed, not eager to repeat the day yet anoth time. With the radio off, Phil does the deejays' morning routine himself, seemingly for the millionth time.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (DULLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, campers, rise and shine, and don't forget your booties because it's cooooold out there today. Phil continues the radio report at his own pace, obviousl fatigued.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: It's cold out there everyday. What is this -- Miami Beach? Haw. Not hardly. And you can expect hazardous travel later today with that, you know, blizzard thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is walking through the crowd. He spots Nancy, walks her and greets her half-heartedly .

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hi, Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (PLEASANTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Do I know you? Phil can't manage enough enthusiasm to pursue her yet aga

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, I guess not. I thought you were someone else. Phil wanders over to where Rita and Larry are setting up camera. Rita comes over to him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Phil? You look terrible. Phil looks at her sadly, then turns away.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (VACANTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ' m fine.

dialogues.speaker: INT . BIKER BAR
dialogues.text: The balls CRACK as the cue ball breaks the rack. Phil is walking around the table, cue in hand, sinking ba after ball, while several admiring HUSTLERS look on.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST HUSTLER
dialogues.text: Who is this guy?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND HUSTLER
dialogues.text: I don't know. Hey, mister-- (Phil doesn't stop

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING
dialogues.text: Who are you, anyway? Phil shoots, sinks a tough one.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You don't know me? I've been playing here every day for two months.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST HUSTLER
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? So how come I ain't seen you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I don't know. I seen you.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND HUSTLER
dialogues.text: So what's your name?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: They call me-- Punxsutawney Phil.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND HUSTLER
dialogues.text: Punxsutawney Phil? Like the groundhog.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, like the groundhog. Phil sinks another one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is waiting expectantly for the groundhog to app Phil is a wreck, squatting unprofessionally in front of t camera.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (CYNICALLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is one of the most pitiful spectacles known to civilization. With one nod from a filthy rodent best known to pest control agencies, a moribund old coal mining hamlet turns magically into the Lourdes of Pennsylvania, Mecca to thousands of people who, if they hated the winter so damned much, why don't they move to Florida, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry and Rita look on, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The program JEOPARDY! is playing.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX TREBECK
dialogues.text: (on TV) Nobel prize-winning co- discoverers of the DNA molecule.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Who are Watson and Crick.

dialogues.speaker: CONTESTANT
dialogues.text: (on TV) Who are Watson and Crick?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (on TV) Correct. There is a cheering from a small group of people off-scre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is sitting in his bathrobe in a big lounge chair in parlor of his hotel. Mrs. Lancaster, and other guests wat his performance, awed by his "intellect."

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (on TV) Twin brother and sister Sebastian and Olivia create confusion in this Shakespearean comedy.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What is "Twelfth Night."

dialogues.speaker: CONTESTANT
dialogues.text: (on TV) What is "Twelfth Night?"

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (on TV) Correct. More cheering from the small group.

dialogues.speaker: CONTESTANT
dialogues.text: (on TV) I'll take New Jersey for eight hundred, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (on TV) And the answer is-- an audio daily double.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Count Basie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is walking through town, still dressed only in his p and overcoat, counting the sidewalk cracks, taking giants from one to the next. He looks crazy.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Two thousand six hundred and s e ve n ty -o n e-- (takes another step) two thousand six hundred and se v en t y -t w o -- (another step) two thousand six hundred and seventy-thr-ee-^- A woman passes walking her dog.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hey, pick up after your dog!

dialogues.speaker: DOG WALKER
dialogues.text: He hasn't done anything.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: He's going to! (POINTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There and there. And there! Phil continues walking, counting the sidewalk cracks. THR NEIGHBORHOOD KIDS notice Phil and walk along, matching hi for step.

dialogues.speaker: IPHIL
dialogues.text: Two thousand six hundred and seventy-four, two thousand six hundred and seventy-five, two

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Five million eight hundred--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: S i x hundred--

dialogues.speaker: MIKE AND SUE
dialogues.text: Ninety, twenty, four, six, fifty--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Two thousand, four hundred--

dialogues.speaker: JOEY, MIKE AND SUE
dialogues.text: Two, eight, nine, forty-six-- Phil stops. He has lost count. His lip curls up like an animal as he turns slowly, growling at the kids. They run screaming with glee. Phil starts after them but runs righ into a COP.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: You got a problem, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (out of control) Yeah, I got a problem, buddy! I can't stand this place anymore! I can't stand this street and I can't stand the fourteen bars and the five banks and the one star food and the bad weather and the "quaint" little shops and most of all, I can't stand anything-- ANYTHING-- with a groundhog on it. He rips a groundhog patch off the cop's jacket sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (CALMLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Then let's see what we can do about getting you out of here. You got a name?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (eyes downcast) Phil.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Phil. Like the groundhog! Phil turns to the cop like a rabid dog, ready to strike.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, like the-- (he stops as if struck) --groundhog. Some big new idea has formed in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: EXT . GOBBLER'S KNOB
dialogues.text: Rita is looking at Phil as Larry videotapes his report.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (turning to Rita) The guy's nuts. He's out of his gourd.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Let him finish, then I'll call the station. They turn back to watch Phil's wrap-up. Phil is completely unkempt, still wearing only pajama bot and his overcoat, looking even more demented.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to camera) There is no way this winter is ever going to end as long as that groundhog keeps seeing his shadow everyday. I don't see any other way out. He's got to be stopped and I've got to stop him. For Channel 9 news, this is Phil Connors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is walking around the mound, casing it out. He takes rifle out from under his coat and sneaks up to the burrow pulls a smoke bomb from his pocket, lights it, and throws into the hole, then scurries for the edge of the knob and the deck. He lifts his rifle and aims it. Smoke is now pouring from the mound. Lots of it. Phil waits, his trigger finger twitching. A WOMAN casually walks by, stops. She surveys the situati

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: He ain't there. Phil doesn't move. He-doesn't care that she sees him.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You can wait all night, but he ain't coming out. He don't live there. They keep him in the library. Phil's gun droops. The woman begins to walk off, then sto

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Plug him once for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil passes a pedestal bearing a life-size bronze statue groundhog and enters the public library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil walks past the front desk looking very haggard and dangerous, and enters the children's section. No one is present except the CHILDREN'S LIBRARIAN, a young woman, reshelving books in the stacks. He looks around quickly a sees a window in the wall and over it a large sign which "Punxsutawney Phil - The Great Prognosticates" Phil heads right for it. The groundhog scurries around his little temperature-cont habitat, oblivious to the approaching danger. As Phil approaches the groundhog display, he reaches into overcoat and pulls out a pump shotgun with a short pistol The children's librarian sees the gun and freezes. Phil pumps a shell into the chamber as he walks right up case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The groundhog looks right into his sights. Philsqueezes the trigger. LOUD GUNSHOT. The glass window is still intact, not a scratch on it. Th groundhog looks up playfully. Phil fires off four more rounds but, again, no results. P can't believe it. He charges the glass and pounds it with rifle butt. He can't even chip it. Suddenly he is seized behind by TWO STRONG MEN who take the rifle from him and wrestle him to floor. The librarian comes running up and looks at the groundhog

dialogues.speaker: BYSTANDER
dialogues.text: Is he all right?

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: He's just fine. That's two inches of bullet-proof glass there. You can't be too careful in this day and age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The groundhog is just poking his head out of the hole. He stands full height and looks around. Phil looks directly at the groundhog with hate and schemi madness. Suddenly, Phil whips out a big kitchen knife from under h icoat and dives at the groundhog. Town officials and poli throw themselves on Phil as the groundhog scampers safely into his hole. Rita and Larry videotape the incident, aghast at Phil's i attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry and Rita are loading their equipment back into the Rita spots Phil standing on the other side of the crowd, staring at her. She marches straight over to him, furious

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Where were you this morning? How could you possibly miss the shoot?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (at the end of his

dialogues.speaker: ROPE
dialogues.text: I've come to the end of me, Rita. There's only one way out now. Just remember/we had a wonderful day together once. Phil kisses her gently on the cheek and walks off toward back of the knob. Rita watches him, then follows at a dis distance, very worried. In a small clearing behind the man-made groundhog burrow, Buster Greene and TWO other GROUNDHOG CLUB OFFICIALS are lifting a cage into the front seat of Buster's pickup.

dialogues.speaker: B USTER
dialogues.text: (to the groundhog) There you go, ol' buddy. Good job. Hey! He smiled at me. See that?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: (securing the cage) There, little fella. The other official looks up and sees Phil walking toward like a zombie.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Hi, there, mister. Something I can do you for? Without a word, Phil jumps quickly into the cab of the pi and starts it up .

dialogues.speaker: FIRST OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Hey! What 're you -- ! Phil drives off in Buster's truck. Rita witnesses the groundhog-napping and runs back toward knob.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (SHOUTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry! Buster and his aides race for another car parked nearby.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Jake! Call the police, and get the word out. Somebody kidnapped Phil. We're going after him. Come on, Tommy! They jump into a car, Buster guns the engine and takes of after the pickup. Rita runs up to Larry and grabs the camera on the fly.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Let's go! Phil just snatched the groundhog! Larry does a slow take and starts gathering up the rest o gear.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (MUTTERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably some kind of gerbil deal. Pervert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil comes tearing around a slippery curve, followed by B in his car, and close behind him, a contingent of police and the Channel 9 news van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil looks at the groundhog on the seat next to him, then punches the gas as he turns up a mountain drive.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Coming to the end of the trail, Phil. Then we're going out in a blaze of glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster pursues Phil with relentless determination.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Nobody takes my groundhog and gets away with it. .. В· .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita is driving. Larry is hooking up the camera.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (very upset) What is he doing? What can he be thinking? He must1 ve just -- snapped. Larry squeezes into the passenger seat with the camera mo on his shoulder .

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: This oughta be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cars chase the pickup to the top of the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Okay! I know this road. There's no way off ' cept the way we come up.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: All right! We got him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup is losing its lead over the pursuers as it nea sharp mountain cliff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil looks in his rearview mirror at the cars chasing him glances down at the groundhog. He takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Okay, pal. It's showtime. Phil hits the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is taping as Rita comes around the curve just in ti see the pickup truck speeding toward the cliff. Rita hits brakes and watches in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup bursts through a retaining fence and rockets o the edge of the cliff. The pickup seems to hang in the air for a long time, then begins its SLOW MOTION descent, falling ever so gracefull until it impacts on the granite rock face far below. BIG EXPLOSION. BIG FIREBALL. FLAMING WRECKAGE. Then a sma click, followed by "I Got You, Babe."

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: He slowly opens his eyes and blinks. He looks around and realizes he's back in his room at the bed and breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Ah, nuts! Phil throws off the covers and hurls himself out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned and a client are huddled over his desk, looking at so papers. A BODY DROPS quickly past the window behind them. It's Phil. They rush to the window and look down at the sidewalk thr stories below. Phil is sprawled there like a broken puppe lifeless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I Got You, Babe" is playing. Phil wakes up and smashes t radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita and Larry are walking down the street when a GREYHOU pulls out of the bus station and accelerates down Main St Suddenly, Phil, dressed in pajamas and overcoat, leaps ou front of the speeding bus. Rita witnesses the whole incid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Phil through the windshield but doesn't even have to hit the brakes before he runs right over Phil.

dialogues.speaker: A TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: A woman in some horror movie is screaming.

dialogues.speaker: REVEAL
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lancaster is watching TV in the parlor of the hotel. the corridor behind her, Phil walks by, dressed in a robe carrying an electric toaster and a towel, heading for the bathroom. A few moments pass. We hear the zap of an electrocution, the lights and TV fl and dim for a moment, then come back on again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building is surrounded by police, all crouched behind cars with guns and rifles trained on the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the doors burst open and Phil comes running out the bank screaming, dressed in camouflage fatigues and ar the teeth with an assault rifle in one hand, an Uzi in th other and a couple of handguns stuck in his belt. He does get three feet before he is shot down in an incredible ha gunfire. Rita stands beside the camera gaping in horror while Larr records the grisly massacre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita stands by weeping while Phil's body is covered with sheet. In the shadowy darkness under the sheet, a CLICK is heard Phil's eyes pop open. "I Got You, Babe" plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil pulls the sheet off his face and finds himself back bed in his room. A tear falls from his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Rita are sitting in the diner at their regular t

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I ' m sorry. What was that again?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'm a god.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You're God?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, I'm A god. Not THE God-- at least I don't think I am.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That's reassuring. For a mintute there I thought you might be crazy.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, it's true. It's the only possible explanation. I'm a supernatural being.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Because you survived a car wreck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter comes to the table.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Are you ready to order?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to Rita, ignoring the

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Not just the car wreck! I didn't just blow up yesterday, you know. I've been run over, drowned, crushed, stabbed, shot, electrocuted, poisoned, frozen, burn ed, and asphyxiated--

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Really? The waiter looks at him like he's nuts.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: --but I always wake up the next day without a scratch, without even a headache. I'm telling you, I ' m immortal.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: The special today is blueberry waffles.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Why are you telling me this?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (SHRUGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because some people like blueberry waffles.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (to the waiter) No t you-- him.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Because I want you to believe in me.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You're not a god, Phil. Take my word for it. This is twelve years of Catholic school talking.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: I could come back if you're not ready.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: How do you know I'm not a god?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Because it's not possible.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: I'll come back. The /waiter turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hey, Billy! The waiter turns back.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: This is Bill. He's been a waiter for three years because he left Penn State and had to find work. He likes the town, he paints toy soldiers, and he's gay.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: I am notl Phil grabs an astonished Rita and pulls her over to the n table.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: This is Doris Kleiser and her fiance Fred.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Do I know you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: They're supposed to get married tonight but Doris is having second thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: What! Doris touces her engagement ring, dumbfounded. Rita is a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Lovely ring.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil drags Rita to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: This is Ralph. Say "Hi," Rita. Rita flashes a quick smile.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Don't believe I've had the--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Ralph hates his life here and wants to drive around town smashing into policemen.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Well, who don't?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: This is some kind of trick.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yes, it's a trick. But maybe the real God cheats, too. Maybe God isn't omnipotent-- he's just had a lot of practice.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: How about that guy?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Tom. Worked in the coal mine В·til they shut it down.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Her?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL '
dialogues.text: Nancy. Went to Lincoln High School in Pittsburgh. Takes herself out to lunch once a week. Rita is getting very bewildered. From their reactions she see that Phil is right about each and every one of them.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: How do you know these people!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I told you the truth. In five seconds there's going to be a grease fire in the kitchen. Five, four--

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: This is nuts.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: --three, two, one. Phil points to the kitchen as smoke starts pouring from t service window. Everyone in the diner is now staring at t

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (trying to puzzle it

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Okay, enough. Let's just sit down and think for a second. (they sit) What do you know about me, Phil? Do you know me, too? Phil takes a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I know all about you, Rita. I know you like producing, but hope for better than Channel 9, Pittsburgh.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Everyone knows that.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You like boats but not the ocean. There's a lake you go to in the summer with your family, up in the mountains, with an old wooden dock and a boathouse with boards missing in the roof, and a place you used to crawl underneath to be alone, and at night you'd look up and see the stars. You're a sucker for Rocky Road, Marlon Brando, and French poetry. You're wonderfully generous; you're kind to strangers, and children; and when you stand in the snow, you look like an angel.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: How are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I told you! I wake up every day right here, right in Punxsutawney, and it's always February second and I can't turn it off. If you still don't bel iev e me, listen--

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: B u t , Phil--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Listen! In ten seconds Larry is going to walk through that door and take you away from me.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Larry?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: But you can't let him. Please believe me. You've got to believe me.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don't -- Larry pokes his head in the doorway, looks around and spo Rita.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Look. As Rita turns around to see Larry, Phil grabs a pen and p from a passing waitress and quickly writes something down Larry makes his way to their table. Phil finishes writing

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to Rita) You ready? We better get going if we're going to stay ahead of the weather. Phil hands the paper to Rita. She reads it.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (READING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: " . . . stay ahead of the weather. " Larry looks at the paper.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What ' s that? Rita looks at Phil with new understanding and empathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Rita are walking down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Afer I got over the shock, it was kind of fun for the first year or two. I had anything I wanted. Except you, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil abruptly pulls Rita aside. A big pile of snow slides a roof and onto the sidewalk where they would have walked Phil doesn't even look up. Rita looks, as if she's seeing miracle.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: How did this start?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I don't know. I just woke up. Just like always. NED RY-ERSON approaches.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Hey, Phil! Phil Connors 1

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Rita, this is Ned Ryerson. He's an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: He remembers me! Phil and Rita keep walking. Rita looks back at Ned, perpl

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Trust me on that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Rita come out of the shop, sharing pieces of fud

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: This is great.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, it isn't. You hate fudge.

dialogues.speaker: . RITA
dialogues.text: Just how well do we know each other?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I told you. I know everybody. Rita stops walking.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Did we ever...you know?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (TEASING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we ever! You were an animal.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You're European trained, aren't you. Phil continues walking.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (BLUSHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil! It's not funny. She catches up to him. Phil turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You weren't interested.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (RELIEVED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. She begins walking again.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Not that it would've been so awful.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I just had to know whether to smack you or not.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You did.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Rita are sitting on a park bench.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: So do you believe any of this?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't know how else you could know so much. Maybe it is really happening.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I used to try to stay up all night sometimes. I thought if I could stay conscious I could figure out what was going on, or at least hang onto something from the day before. But I gave up on that a long time ago. Rita looks at him with compassion.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It sounds so-- lonely.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (trying to shrug it

dialogues.speaker: OFF
dialogues.text: It's not that bad. You get used to it. Rita comes to a decision.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Maybe I should spend the rest of the day with you-- as an objective witness. Just to see what happens. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. That'd be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hat is lying on Phil's bed. A playing card flies past. second playing card sails right into the hat. Another pla card sails past, missing. Another playing card sails righ Phil and Rita are tossing cards. Rita is missing. Phil is hitting.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: It's not in the wrist so much as the fingers. Be the hat.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It would take me a year to get good at this.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. Six months. Four, five hours a day.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Is this what you do with eternity?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Now you know. It's like waiting for a bus that never comes . You should see me play pool -- and bowling, juggling, hacky sack. I can ride a unicycle. There ' s a knock on the door .

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'll get it! Phil jumps for the door and opens it. The PIZZA GUY is th

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hi, Marty. $11.75 including the delivery charge, right?

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA GUY
dialogues.text: U h hh h -- Phil pays him, takes the pizza and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (opening the pizza box) MMMM. Pepperoni and olives. My favorite .

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Of course. I told you, I know everything .

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (taking a bite of

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA
dialogues.text: I don ' t think I ' d want to know everything that ' s going to happen. I like to be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: That's not the worst part.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What's the worst part?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: The worst part is starting over everyday. Tomorrow you won't remember any of this. You'll go back to treating me like a complete jerk --

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: It's not your fault. I am a jerk.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No, you're not.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Okay, I ' m not. It really doesn't make a lot of difference. I've killed myself so many times, I don't even exist anymore. I'm just completely empty.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Or completely clean.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: If you're going to be this positive all the time I may have to rough you up a little.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Wait! Have we done this before?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Which part?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You getting me up here, the card gam e, the pizza--

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, this is the first time.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (EXCITED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Well, what?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well how does it feel to be doing something completely new? Phil looks at her with tremendous affection and gratitude

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Good. Really good. He takes a slice of pizza and starts eating with gusto.

dialogues.speaker: THE PIZZA BOX
dialogues.text: There's only one slice left. Phil and Rita are sitting together on the bed, close but touching. Soft music is playing on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wish I had a thousand lifetimes. One to be a great journalist. One to, I don't know, go back to school, study art, or auto mechanics. One just to take care of all the busywork, you know, pay the bills, get my car tuned up. One to be the wild woman of Borneo. One to be Mother Theresa. Maybe it's not a curse, Phil. It all just depends on how you look at it. Phil stares at her for a long time letting this sink in. he belches really loud. Rita stares at him, then burps surprisingly loud herself.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I want you to know, it's been a really nice day for me.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Maybe, if it's not too boring for you, we could do it again.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I hope so. The clock reads 11:59. Rita grabs Phil's hand. He puts hi arm around her. They look into each others' eyes. Rita gives Phil a reass smile. She squeezes his hand. Their eyes turn to the cloc 11:;59 turns to 12:00. Rita looks up at Phil as if expecting some magical event.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You're still here!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I thought you were supposed to disappear-- or I was or something.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Not 'til six.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You rat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is mad in a playful way.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I never said midnight--

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You knew I was waiting for midnight!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: But I never said it.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, I can't believe you! (she slugs him with a

dialogues.speaker: PILLOW
dialogues.text: I didn't know this was going to take all night!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Does that mean you're going?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No. Phil takes Rita's hand. She doesn't resist.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Rita is now sitting right next to Phil on the bed, her he resting on his shoulder. She nods off then catches hersel

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: It's okay to go to sleep you know. I promise I won't touch you-- much.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No, it's all right. I'm not tired. What were you saying? Her eyes start to close again.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I was saying that the cow was eventually returned to it's rightful owner.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (drifting off) Really?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: That's right. He looks at her, sees she's truly asleep, and gently mane her into a comfortable reclining position on the bed. The carefully puts a pillow under her head and settles down n her.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What I was going to say was, I think you're the kindest, sweetest, prettiest, most wonderful girl I ever met in my life. She starts to stir but he gently kisses her back to sleep

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Shhhh. That's good. (satisfied she's still

dialogues.speaker: ASLEEP
dialogues.text: I could never tell you this, but from the first minute I looked at you I wanted to just hold you close and be with you forever. iEverytime I -saw you around the station, I thought my heart was going to explode. I used to dream about us being together. In my dream you loved me as much as I loved you and we didn't have to say anything but I knew you understood everything. She stirs again but he kisses her until she returns to de sleep.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I know a guy like me could never deserve to have someone like you, but if I did, I swear I would love you for the rest of my life. Rita opens her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (HALF-ASLEEP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say something?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Good-night, Rita. He kisses her gently on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Good-night, Phil.

dialogues.speaker: C LOSE UP
dialogues.text: The time changes from 5:59 to 6:00. The radio starts play Phil wakes up alone in bed. He lies there for a moment th leaps out of bed like a man reborn and heads straight for shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita and Larry are in the packed press area, beginning to up the equipment. Phil arrives, carrying two cups of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Rita? She looks at him without a trace of the rapport they shar night before.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, hi, Phil.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Thought you might like some-- He hands her the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Thanks!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Careful, it's hot. Larry? He hands Larry a cup.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (surprised, mutters) Yeah, great.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: We're just setting up.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You know, I bumped into Buster Greene, he kind of runs this thing, and he tipped me off that we might get a better shot over there.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I mean, maybe we should go for it. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Sounds good to me. Larry?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sure, why not?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: All right. Thanks, Phil. Good work. She reaches for an equipment case.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'll get that. Phil helps Larry carry the camera gear.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to Larry) You and I never talk, Larry. You got kids? Larry looks suspicious. Rita looks on, reevaluating Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil enters the library, approaches the Librarian.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Where would I find the Philosophy section?

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Down and to the left, 600's. Phil walks through the stacks, past the groundhog window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil rings the doorbell. A kindly young woman, MARY, answ

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I ' d like a piano lesson, please.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay, I ' m with a student now, but --

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'll give you a thousand dollars. Mary hesitates only a moment, then ushers Phil into the h and closes the door. A moment later the door opens and a LITTLE GIRL with an a of music books exits as if pushed. The door closes behind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil walks happily down the hallway. He passes the chubby

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY MAN
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Buon Giorno, signore. / '.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY MAN
dialogues.text: Think it ' 11 be an early Spring?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: "Winter slumbering in the open air wears on his smiling face a dream of Spring."

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY MAN
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Mary are sitting together at the piano. Phil is playing, poorly.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not bad, Mr. Connors. You say this is your first lesson?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Technically, yes. Phil plays on, definitely improving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see several cuts of Phil studying at the library. SUPERED over these cuts is a calendar with the pages flip by. They all read "February 2 . "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil stands in front of the camera, giving his report.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: In fact, the groundhog's legendary ability to predict the weather may be more than just the German folklore of the region. Higher temperatures trigger hormonal changes in the testosterone levels of male groundhogs, which may in fact wake them from hibernation and send them out to battle with other males ;for mating rights. So, the truth is they're not looking for their shadows, they're looking for groundhog chicks. Rita looks on, clearly delighted with the report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is playing the piano with ever increasing skill as m February 2 calendar pages flip by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is delivering another report.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Groundhog Day, February second, also known as Candlemas Day or the Feast of the Purification of the Virgin Mary, the day Mary first came to the temple for ritual blessings following the birth of the infant Jesus, and celebrated since the Middle Ages by the sacramental lighting of candles. Hence the old Scottish couplet which long predates the .American groundhog tradition: "If Candlemas dawns bright and clear, there'll be two winters in the year." Larry whispers an aside to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Is he making this stuff up?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (RIVETED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond the graveyard is a work shed with various tombston scattered about. Old TUCKER, the town stonecarver, is at chiseling a name into a gravemarker. Behind him, Phil is chipping away at a small hunk of marb sculpting a very lovely cherub. Rita sits on a stool eating an apple and sipping hot tea watching him with amazed interest.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: But what if the rules changed? What if none of your actions had consequences?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: There would still be an absolute morality. There has to be an absolute good, regardless of the circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh, is that so, Miss Plato? Then let me ask you this. Where does this "absolute good" come from? From the sky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don't know. From my freshman Philosophy course, I guess. They both laugh. Then she looks at him for a long moment grins.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just can't believe you're such a fine sculptor. Phil takes a bite of her apple and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Where do you have to go in Punxsutawney?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I got piano and then drums.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Come on, I'll drop you off. They exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil drops Rita off and watches as she crosses the street Larry who is waiting on the other side. Across the street, Rita takes a wistful glance toward Phi then gets in the news van and drives off. Phil gets out of the car and starts walking, but finds hi face to face with Ned Ryerson.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Phil! Phil Connors! I thought that was you!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Ned? Ned Ryerson! I don't believe it. I've missed you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil gives Ned a big hug and keeps holding on for an uncomfortably long time, actually giving Ned a hickey on neck. Ned goes into homophobic shock.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Uh, I gotta get going. Nice to see you, Phil. He hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is sitting on the piano bench with Mary, playing pre well. Mary is astonished.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How long have you been studying, Mr. Connors?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: One day. I'm gifted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is walking down the street. He glances down the alle he passes, stops, walks back and enters the alley. The OL that Phil never noticed before is lying there, huddled ag a wall. Phil goes to help him.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hey, mister. Hey. Come on, let's get you somewhere warm. The old bum turns to look at Phil, then closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (helps the old man to his feet) There you go. Phil practically carries him out of the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nurse approaches Phil.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You the one brought in the old man?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: How is he?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: He passed away just now. Phil pauses for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What'd he die of?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (SHRUGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was just old. It was his time.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I want to see his chart. Excuse me. Phil brushes past her and makes for the big double doors leading to triage.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Sir, you can't -- (hurrying after him) Look! Some people just die!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Not on my watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is propping up the old man at a table, trying to fee hot soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is furiously looking over X-rays, flipping through m journals and making notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is in the alley, shaking the old man, trying to rous

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Come on . Hang on . Hang on , there . Breathe .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil stops. The body lies, unmoving. Phil sits back, breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is delivering his report. Everyone there is silent a listening to Phil. Even the other reporters have turned t cameras on him.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: ...When Chekhov saw the long winter, it was a winter bleak and dark and bereft of hope; and yet, we know winter's only one more step in the cycle. And standing among the people of Punxsutawney -- (Phil looks directly at

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: -- basking in the warmth of their hearths and hearts, I couldn't imagine a better fate than a long and lustrous winter. Phil smiles. Rita smiles, too.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: For Channel 9 news, I ' m Phil Connors. There is much applause. Even Larry brushes away a tear. Phil hands the microphone to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'm gonna be late. Phil rushes off.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Late for what? Phil? (To Larry) Could you break it down and wrap out of here by yourself, Larry?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sure .

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Thanks .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita rushes off after Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil walks briskly toward an intersection, glancing nervo at his watch. Rita follows him at a distance, hurrying to up. MARIE, a little nine-year-old girl, approaches the inters shielding her brand new puppy under her winter coat. She paying attention to traffic and fails to notice a big tru bearing down on her. As she steps off the curb, Phil arrives and, with split-s timing, nonchalantly but firmly grabs her coat to hold he back, just as the big truck rushes past in the street, na missing her.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hey! Did you forget to look both ways? You didn't even look one way.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: My doggie was cold.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, my doggies are freezing, but I ' m still gonna watch out for cars. See you around, kid. Phil looks at his watch and rushes off. Rita looks on amazed and follows him at a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil enters the crowded restaurant and pushes past all th people waiting to be seated. He walks casually but quickl purposefully around the tables, squeezing past busy waitr and seated patrons toward a commotion in the back of the restaurant. TWO BUSINESSMEN are leaning over a THIRD.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! He's having a heart attack!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Lay him down!

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: What do I do? He's not

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: He's turning blue! Help! Phil walks straight up to the BLUE-FACED MAN, grabs him f behind, gets him in the Heimlich grip and squeezes sharpl A bolus of food flies across the room. The victim coughs sputters, then starts breathing again.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Jerry, you okay?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: I think that did it. Phil lets go of the grateful victim.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: If you're going to eat steak, get better teeth, will you? Enjoy the rest of your lunch, gents. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Wow. Who was that guy? Phil gets to the door and finds Rita standing there, look him in awe.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Rita!

dialogues.speaker: .RITA
dialogues.text: (CONFRONTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Okay, hold it right there. I want to know what' s going on and I want to know right now.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm really pressed right now. Meet me outside the hospital about 5:00 and we'll talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: The hospital? Phil looks at his watch and rushes away.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Try the curlycue fries. Killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gurney bursts through the double doors, paramedics and in attendance. The patient is a teenage girl, JANEY, tota unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gurney is wheeled into the surgery.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Looks like insulin shock. She's probably diabetic. Phil enters wearing a doctor's scrub suit and begins bark orders.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: She's not diabetic. It's an overdose. Let's get her up here and pump her stomach, then I want a complete blood work-up, STAT.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: R i g h t , Doctor--uh-- She realizes she's never seen him before.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Call me Phil.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Phil. Like the groundhog?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick CHILDREN in hospital gowns are gathered around Phil, laughing and squealing. Phil is. making balloon animals.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Make a giraffe!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: A giraffe? Let's see. It's just like a dog with a biiiiig-- what was it?

dialogues.speaker: ALL THE KIDS
dialogues.text: Neck!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: A big tail? Okay, a big tail.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Neck! A big neck! Phil makes an animal really quickly. Rita watches from the doorway, unseen by Phil.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: There. A dog with long legs.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Nooo ! Long neck !

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh! Right! A dog with a big head.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Noooo! The kids attack Phil. Lots of rolling around on the bed. watches, completely enthralled. Finally, Phil extricates himself and exits to find Rita waiting.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: All right, now what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (taking her arm) Come on. We have to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: EXT . RESIDENTIAL STREET
dialogues.text: Phil rushes down the sidewalk with Rita close behind him. stops under a tree and puts his arms out just as a YOUNG falls out of the tree and into his arms, knocking him to ground. The kid runs off unhurt as Phil gets back to his and brushes himself off.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (to Rita) That little bastard has never thanked me once . I ought to j ust let him fall. Teach him a lesson.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Phil, this is too -- I must be dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, you and me both. Come on, We're almost done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil kneels on the cold ground beside the old bum who lie huddled against the wall, immobile. Rita is standing by at the end of the alley, watching as examines him. Phil writes something down on a small pad. He finishes, a sets it down by the old man. Then he takes his coat and u it to cover the man up. A siren is heard. Phil stands and walks away, as an ambulance pulls into th alley.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Is he -- ?

dialogues.speaker: . 'PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: In a minute. She waits and watches. The paramedics, BUD and ANDY, get out of the ambulance an inspect the scene.

dialogues.speaker: BUD
dialogues.text: It's ol1 Really.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: That's a shame.

dialogues.speaker: BUD
dialogues.text: Look here . Bud picks up the note Phil left. Rita steps closer.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: May I see that? (reading aloud) "Every night, by cold bricks

dialogues.speaker: GLOW
dialogues.text: I watch the shadow rising from this old man in the snow. At 8:02 we let it go."

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (REPEATING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "At 8:02 we let it go."

dialogues.speaker: BUD
dialogues.text: Wow, that's nice. Rita hands him the note and quickly walks away.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Suppose he wrote it?

dialogues.speaker: BUD
dialogues.text: (DOUBTFUL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita catches up with Phil outside the Pennsylvanian, the oldest and best hotel.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Come on. You'll see. They enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Phil and Rita enter there is music coming from a side The black velvet announcement board proclaims: KLEISER-SC WEDDING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Rita walk into a banquet room decorated with streamers, balloons and flowers. There is a long buffet t and a punch bowl. Another long table is loaded with weddi gifts. A small band is playing. People are dancing. The wedding party is dressed in rente tuxedos and appropriately pouffy bridesmaid dresses.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: This is incredible. Who's wedding is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil grabs two glasses of champagne and hands one to Rita

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Just some friends. Dorisi The bride, DORIS, young and cheery, is on her way to see She is dragging FRED, her groom, with her.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Hi, Mr. Connors! Come ON, Freddy.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: This is the guy I told you about.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: No way!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: How's it going, Fred?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hey, I ' d like to thank you for making Doris go through with this.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Don't buy that playing hard to get stuff. She's crazy about you, you stud.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I ' m really glad you could come.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Congratulations. Phil reaches into his pocket, pulls out two tickets and h them to Doris.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What is this? Oh, no way! No way! Ahhh! Doris throws herself on Fred and jumps up and down. Fred the tickets.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Wrestlemania! No way! No way! Doris throws herself on Phil.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: We're like going to be in Pittsburgh anyway.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I don't know. I just thought about you two, tried to picture what you ' d want more than anything in the world and it came to me. Bing! Wrestlemania.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mr. Connors. You're a real pal.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: This is the best! Doris gives Phil a kiss. She and Fred move on.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don ' t understand . You rush from one person to the next in a town you only visit once a year, you know everything before it happens , and you -- - I don ' t know , you seem to be Punxsutawney ' s leading citizen. The band finishes a set. The guests stop dancing and head the refreshments. Phil and Rita are left alone for the mo

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I really don't know.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No, there's something going on with you.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Okay, I wake up in Punxsutawney on February second -- every day. It's supernatural. I don't even try to explain it anymore. So, I live each day as if it's the only day I've got. Rita stares into his eyes for a very long time, but sees good, true things.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That's pretty amazing. "

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You want to know what's really amazing? I've been waiting for you every day for ten thousand years. I dream of you every night of my life. You've been my constant weapon against total despair, and just knowing you exist has kept me alive. How's that? Rita can't even speak. This is clearly the nicest thing anybody has ever said to anybody. Mary the piano teacher notices Phil.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Phil! (to her friend) This is the guy.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Hello, Mary. Rita, this is one of Punxsey's finest musicians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a break. You should talk. Why don't you play something?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: N o , I--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hey, Mr. Connors. Go for it. Phil looks at Rita. She nods and shrugs. Phil walks up to the platform and sits at the piano. He b to play a slow, serious, classical piece. Everyone falls silent. It's so beautiful, Rita is almost in tears. Then, after a pause to let the serious notes sink in, Phi transforms the piece into a fast, lively, upbeat jazz rom Everyone is delighted, and as the rest of the band kicks everyone grabs a partner and begins to dance. An old coot, UNCLE LEO, grabs Rita and the two of them da a storm.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: That's a great guy you've got there. Doctor Connors fixed my back, you know.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Do ctor Connors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rit a looks over at Phil, joyously playing the piano.
